entry.title: SLT ISSUE IN S4HANA MIGRATION
entry.content:
Hi Everyone,

We have a scenario where our ECC system is being migrated to S/4HANA. In the current setup, data from ECC is replicated to a HANA database using SLT.

Post-migration, the SLT source system will be updated to S/4HANA. We have more than 800 tables being replicated from ECC to HANA today, and after migration, we need to continue replicating these tables (wherever they still exist and are not obsolete in S/4HANA).

Has anyone worked on a similar scenario and can share:

Cutover / data load strategy for such a large volume of tables

Challenges faced during replication from S/4HANA, especially regarding:

Data type mismatches between source and target

Additional fields appearing in S/4 tables

Handling obsolete or replaced tables

 

Any insights, lessons learned, or best practices would be really helpful.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Re: How to Prevent MRP from Covering Shortages Before the...
entry.content:
MRP still covering early shortages: how to force ‚Äúplan only to future PIRs‚Äù

You‚Äôve done the right things conceptually (time fence + forward-only consumption), but two typical culprits still let early sales erode future PIRs: residual PIR consumption/reduction settings and proposal creation/rescheduling allowed inside or up to the fence. Here‚Äôs how to lock it down so MRP proposals align only with the PIR horizon.

Key fixes to try

1) Eliminate cross-period PIR reduction entirely

  • Set consumption to none at the MRP Group.

    • Consumption mode: 0 (No consumption), and keep backward/forward = 0/0.

    • Assign the MRP Group to the materials so they inherit this rule.

  • Turn off PIR reduction by sales altogether.

    • In the requirement class/strategy used for PIRs, switch off ‚ÄúReduce requirements‚Äù so sales orders cannot reduce PIRs.

    • If you don‚Äôt need sales to consume PIRs at all, choose a strategy group that does not consume PIRs, or override via MRP Group.

  • Why: Your current forward window (60 days) still allows earlier sales to nibble at future PIRs that fall inside that 60-day lookahead. ‚ÄúNo consumption + no reduction‚Äù is the clean break.

2) Enforce a hard planning window for proposal creation

  • Planning time fence (PTF): Keep 79 days, but pair it with a firming type that disallows new order proposals and rescheduling inside the PTF.

    • Use a firming type that:

      • Does not create new proposals inside the PTF, and

      • Does not reschedule-in existing proposals into the PTF.

  • Planning horizon (days): Maintain at plant/MRP Group level so the system only creates proposals for dates within your intended future window (beyond ‚Äúnow,‚Äù not before it).

  • Why: Even if there‚Äôs a ‚Äúshortage‚Äù today, MRP won‚Äôt be allowed to propose anything before your horizon.

3) Align lot sizing to PIR buckets

  • Lot size: Use period lot sizing (weekly/monthly) that matches your PIR cadence or a fixed lot size per bucket.

  • Why: MRP then creates one clean PR per bucketed PIR, instead of multiple ‚Äúgap-filling‚Äù PRs.

4) Tame rescheduling and exceptions

  • Rescheduling horizon: Set to 0 (or minimal) so you don‚Äôt get reschedule-in proposals that pull supply into the near term.

  • Exception messages: Disable or down-prioritize ‚Äúreschedule-in‚Äù inside the PTF to avoid operational pressure to cover the past.

 

Master data checks on a sample material

  • MRP Group assigned: Confirms the material inherits ‚Äúno consumption, no reduction‚Äù and PTF behavior.

  • Strategy group / requirements type for PIRs: Use a variant where PIRs are not reduced by sales orders; if unsure, enforce at MRP Group level.

  • Consumption fields blank at material level: So MRP Group settings dominate (no accidental overrides).

  • Scheduling margins / safety time: Ensure these don‚Äôt pull dates forward into the fence.

  • Availability check / scope: Avoid settings that advance requirement dates or create hidden near-term coverage pressure.

 

If standard config still isn‚Äôt enough

  • Consider a small enhancement to enforce your policy:

    • Flexible PIR consumption: Enhancement to block any sales-order consumption of PIRs outside the exact PIR bucket window (or entirely).

    • Change MRP data during the run: Suppress proposal creation for demands dated before the horizon or reclassify them as non-plannable.

  • These are lightweight and commonly used when business policy requires ‚Äúfuture-only‚Äù planning regardless of historical gaps.

 

Quick diagnostic to pinpoint the leak

  1. Run MRP with:

    • Consumption mode = 0, back/fwd = 0/0 at MRP Group.

    • Firming type that forbids creation/rescheduling inside the 79-day PTF.

    • Rescheduling horizon = 0.

  2. Check:

    • Do PIR quantities remain intact despite past overselling? If yes, consumption/reduction was the issue.

    • Do any PRs appear inside the PTF? If yes, firming/rescheduling settings need tightening.

    • Are PRs dated neatly to PIR buckets? If not, adjust lot sizing to period-based buckets.

entry.title: Moderation on SAP Community
entry.content:
SAP Community moderators ensure that the content on our site and that our members comply with our rules of engagement, as well as with other policies and guidelines (such as the Digital Services Act). They review content submitted to the site (particularly content from new members) and respond to reports about rules violations. They also monitor the site for potential violations.

Upon discovering violations, moderators may remove content, alter content (to bring it into compliance), ban members (either temporarily or permanently, depending on the severity of the violation), or issue warnings. Where necessary, they‚Äôll ensure that all actions follow the Digital Services Act (DSA). Whenever possible, they‚Äôll coach members to help them understand and follow our rules, as their primary goal is to create a positive environment where members can contribute and grow.

The moderation team follows several processes -- based on the type of content submitted or the nature of a violation. 

Pre-Moderation for New Members 

Questions, answers, discussions, and comments from newer members (not employed by SAP) pass through pre-moderation. This pre-moderation ensures that this content complies with our rules of engagement and reduces the likelihood of spam and other inappropriate content appearing on SAP Community. (To learn about moderation for blog posts and knowledge-base documents, please see the next section.) 

When newer members submit questions, answers, discussions, and comments for SAP Community, their content will enter a pre-moderation queue, where it will be reviewed to ensure compliance with our rules. They will also receive a message informing them that their content requires pre-moderation. 

Upon submission new members will be notified that the post is in moderation, and will be released if it is approved: 

You can find your queue of unmoderated posts, and their status here. If the content is appropriate, it will be published. If it isn‚Äôt, it won‚Äôt. Spam will be removed from the queue before reaching the site, and anyone caught attempting to publish spam will be banned.  
Pre-moderation takes up to two hours, Monday through Friday. New members who submit content over the weekend will need to wait until Monday before pre-moderation takes place. 

To bypass pre-moderation, newer members will need to demonstrate that they understand our guidelines and are willing to comply with our rules. Over time, once they‚Äôve shown that they wish to contribute positively to SAP Community ‚Äì by submitting content that consistently passes through pre-moderation successfully ‚Äì they‚Äôll gain the ability to post directly to the site. We won‚Äôt share any details beyond that, as we don‚Äôt want to give spammers information that will help them work around pre-moderation. Also, we don‚Äôt reveal details about gamification, the rank ladder, and privileges because per our FAQs, we want to ‚Äúkeep members focused on general quality participation.‚Äù  

Note that the pre-moderation process doesn‚Äôt apply to established members who have been contributing regularly to SAP Community. It also doesn‚Äôt apply to knowledge-base documents and blog posts ‚Äì just to other types of content (e.g., questions, answers, discussions, comments/replies in threads). The process for blogging and document moderation remains unchanged. 

Blog and Document Moderation 

To blog, members (whether employed by SAP or not) must first complete our SAP Community tutorial, ensuring that they take all of the actions outlined in the tutorial. 

Curators or owners review all blog posts submitted to their groups. They decide whether the content is appropriate for a group‚Äôs audience. They conduct these reviews, and make their decisions, independently of the SAP Community moderation team. 

Elsewhere in SAP Community, our moderation team reviews submissions from new bloggers for the various ‚Äúby members‚Äù and ‚Äúby SAP‚Äù blog boards. After review, a moderator either approves the post or sends it back to the author with feedback. Blog reviews from our moderation team can take up to five business days for each submission. In other words, if a moderator sends a post back to an author with feedback, and the author makes the necessary changes and submits the post again, it may take up to another five business days before the second review occurs. This process occurs each time the author submits a post for review, so if a member wishes to go through moderation more quickly, he or she should take the time to ensure that the post complies with standards and guidelines, as outlined in the tutorial and the rules of engagement.  

To notify our moderators that your post is ready for them, please make sure that you click the ‚ÄúSubmit for Review‚Äù button in the blogging tool. Save as a draft if you‚Äôre still working on the post. Please don‚Äôt submit a post for review if you plan to keep working on it. Also, please only submit one post at a time for review. Once the moderation team works with you and approves a post, you may work on another and submit it for review.    

To check on the status of your submission, navigate to the Blog Dashboard for the blog board where you submitted your post for review and click ‚ÄúView All Drafts.‚Äù  

After clicking "View All Drafts," you'll see the status, version number, and other information for your submission:‚ÄØ 

By clicking on the submission's title, you can check the history of the submission to see whether a group owner, curator, or moderator provided feedback -- explaining that the post has been rejected or outlining what steps are necessary to qualify for publication.‚ÄØ You just need to click "View History" to get these details:‚ÄØ 

To bypass blog moderation, members need to move up the rank ladder, although groups curators and owners must always approve blog posts for their groups, regardless of the author‚Äôs rank. Members can climb the ranks through consistent, positive activity and contributions. You can learn more about the various SAP Community ranks (and how to climb the rank ladder) in this post. 

To publish a knowledge-base document in a group, members require the approval of a curator or owner for that group. Curators or owners review documents submitted for their knowledge-base boards, determining whether the content is a good fit, just as they review submissions for their blog boards. 

Note that this moderation process doesn‚Äôt apply to questions, answers, discussions, comments, and other content from newer members. This process only applies to the moderation of blog posts and documents. To learn more about the pre-moderation process that applies to questions, answers, replies in threads, etc., please refer to the previous section above.  

Moderation of Content/Members Reported as Inappropriate 

Members can report other members and their content for violations. When they do so, our moderation team will review the report and determine what steps are required (if any). 

You‚Äôll find the option for reporting inappropriate content from the dropdown menu next to posts, answers, comments, etc., throughout the site. Here‚Äôs what you‚Äôll see when reporting a question, for example:

Selecting this option will bring you to a series of menus, as well as a text field, allowing you to provide details about why you‚Äôve reported the content. 

When reporting content, it‚Äôs important to indicate whether the content violates the Digital Services Act (DSA), as DSA violations require additional actions from our moderation team (versus reports for common moderation activities, such as fixing tags).

In most cases, you‚Äôll simply choose ‚ÄúOther alert to moderators‚Äù for the reason ‚Äì as this selection applies to the majority of reports that our moderation team receives (for requests to move content to another area, remove/correct a tag, and so on). 

If you pick ‚ÄúOther alert to moderators‚Äù as the reason, the ‚ÄúDSA Specification‚Äù menu will remain grayed out. (Since the reason is unrelated to a DSA violation, no additional selection is required.) You‚Äôll still have the option to enter additional information (in the ‚ÄúDetails‚Äù field). For example, you can point out an incorrect tag (and propose a better one) before submitting the report by clicking the ‚ÄúNotify Moderator‚Äù button. 

This information helps our moderators understand the nature of the issue and work with members quickly to fix the problem, minus the formality of DSA steps that require stiffly worded messages and legally sounding explanations. For non-DSA cases, the moderators can work with members in a capacity that doesn‚Äôt feel overly official, creating a much friendlier experience for the members involved.  

In situations where something does violate the DSA, our moderation team follows the procedures outlined by this act, including messaging the member reported as well as the member who submitted the report ‚Äì making sure they are aware of the nature of the violation, what steps have been/will be taken, how they can protest a decision, and so on. Given the complexity associated with the management of DSA violations, we ask that you make certain that it‚Äôs a true DSA offense before reporting it as such. 

When alerting the moderation team about a DSA violation, you‚Äôll need to select one of the reasons beneath the dashed line (underneath ‚ÄúNon-DSA related alert to moderators‚Äù), such as ‚ÄúIllegal Or Harmful Speech‚Äù and ‚ÄúUnsafe And/Or Illegal Products.‚Äù 

This action opens the ‚ÄúDSA Specification‚Äù menu, where you‚Äôll need to select the item related to the reason. There are several to choose. 

Since we have mapped these reasons and specifications to DSA systems (which is where we need to upload data about our DSA-related activities), we must make sure that we open and submit every DSA case accurately. You can help by selecting the right reason (distinguishing between non-DSA and DSA alerts) and DSA specification (in the event of actual DSA violations) carefully when reporting content that requires moderation. 

Not sure which selection to make? You‚Äôll see some helpful suggestions right next to the menus, providing guidance about what to select and why for common scenarios. 

As an example, if you want to report spam, select ‚ÄúViolation of Terms of Use‚Äù for the reason and ‚ÄúOther‚Äù from the ‚ÄúDSA Specification‚Äù menu. (Remember to add some information in the details to help our moderators understand why you‚Äôre reporting the content.) 

In addition to reporting content, you can report members. In fact, if a member has published multiple pieces of content that violate our rules, we recommend that you report the member instead of his or her individual posts. That way, our moderation team only needs to process one report (for the member) versus multiple reports (for all of the content). You can report members by clicking on their name anywhere in SAP Community (such as in a byline for a blog post), finding ‚ÄúOptions‚Äù on their content page, and clicking ‚ÄúReport User.‚Äù 

One last piece of important advice: Negative feedback and curt comments aren‚Äôt against the law, and they don‚Äôt qualify as harassment and hate speech under DSA regulations. To be more specific, as an example, DSA defines hate speech as ‚Äúillegal incitement to violence and hatred based on protected characteristics.‚Äù Therefore, before reporting member comments as misconduct under DSA, consider whether they can be categorized as illegal speech. Per our‚ÄØBasic Etiquette and Tips for Participating in SAP Community‚ÄØguidelines, members should keep discourse civil and try to work out differences, reporting member comments only when they are truly harmful and in violation of DSA regulations. Disagreements and criticism are not grounds for moderator action ‚Äì especially under DSA. 

 

Contacting the Moderation Team 

You can learn more about our moderation team on our Points of Contact page. If you have specific questions about moderation actions, please contact‚ÄØmoderators@sap.com.

entry.title: SAP SuccessFactors Customer Conversations with Cadent Gas
entry.content:
We are excited to invite you to our upcoming LIVE event featuring Cadent Gas, the UK's largest gas distribution network. Join us to hear firsthand about Cadent Gas‚Äôs successful HR transformation and how they achieved significant enhancements in employee experience and operational efficiency with SAP SuccessFactors solutions.

Register here!

About Cadent Gas: 
Cadent Gas brings gas to 11 million homes and businesses. With over 6000 employees, the company manages a network of more than 82,000 miles of pipes, most of them underground, which transport gas throughout the Northwest, West Midlands, East Midlands, South Yorkshire, East of England and North London.

Agenda: 

  • Company overview
  • Insights into Cadent Gas‚Äôs HR strategy and the challenges faced
  • Implementation journey using a phased approach
  • Best practices and lessons for success
  • What‚Äôs next: Talent Intelligence Hub, Opportunity Marketplace and AI tools
  • Interactive Q&A session


Challenges and Highlights:
Cadent Gas's HR transformation journey included the phased implementation of SAP SuccessFactors. Starting with the establishment of a dedicated HRIS team and centralizing HR activities, they leveraged SuccessFactors to enhance manager capabilities and streamline HR processes. In the next phase, Cadent Gas implemented Employee Central as the self-service core HR master system, as well as optimizing the recruiting, onboarding, and learning experiences. Cadent Gas is now building on this foundation, by implementing the Talent Intelligence Hub and Opportunity Marketplace, as well as integrating AI tools to accelerate efficiency within their HR operations.

SAP Solutions:
Cadent Gas uses these SAP SuccessFactors solutions: Employee Central, Recruiting, Learning, Performance & Goals, Succession & Development and Onboarding.

entry.title: ROLE AUTHORIZATION PFCG
entry.content:
Good afternoon,

Let's see if someone can help me with this role issue because it's not easy at all.

I've been working with SAP for a while but I can't seem to find the solution. Let me explain:

1) I have a user (USER1) with several assigned roles. This user does not have authorization to access Tx SE16.

2) I have a role created by me (ROL1) that allows access to SE16 and contains the following: - Authorization object S_TCODE - TCD SE16 - Authorization object S_TABU_NAM - ACTVT 03, TABLE ZXX1.

3) I have another empty user (USER2). If I assign the role created by me (ROL1), it works perfectly, and the user has access to SE16 for table ZXX1. If, for example, I try to access table ZXX2, it doesn't let me because there is no authorization. So far, everything is fine.

Now comes the strange part:

4) If I assign my role (ROL1) to user USER1, who has several roles assigned but does not have access to SE16, the user can access SE16 (correct because ROL1 allows it), but in addition to being able to access ZXX1, they can also access ZXX2 and all tables in the system.

Why can they access all tables if they only have access to ZXX1?

How can I configure it so that USER1 can only access certain tables?

Thank you in advance for your help.

entry.title: Re: Object type definition for an outbound IDoc
entry.content:
This topic is quite old by now, but if anyone stumbles across this issue like I just did, there seems to be a note now that provides a solution. (Haven't tested it yet myself)

See 2427697 - Missing outcomming IDOC (DESADV) in ASN (advanced shipping notification) - SAP for Me

As already mentioned beforehand the entry in TBD14 is the problem. By deleting the entry for DESADV, the system is supposed to determine the object type dynamically from the business application.

Cheers!

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytics Cloud add-in for Microsoft Office
entry.content:
Hello,

You will not see the SAP Analytics Cloud add-in automatically. It has to be installed from the Office Add-ins Store by going to Insert ‚Üí Get Add-ins ‚Üí search for ‚ÄúSAP Analytics Cloud.‚Äù If it is not available there, it usually means that your IT has disabled access to the Office Add-ins Store, and in that case the IT administrator needs to deploy it centrally through the Microsoft 365 Admin Center.

From my experience, however, the SAP Analytics Cloud add-in is not as useful as the SAP Analysis for Excel add-in, because the SAC add-in does not support Live BW models and works only with imported models or Datasphere models. For this reason, I personally prefer using the SAP Analysis for Excel add-in.

entry.title: Use case of MMRV

entry.title: Re: Value Mapping usage in XSLT Mappings with CPI
entry.content:
Hi Robert, 

just wanted to point out that your groovy script might return wrong values due to race conditions. This may lead to weird behaviour and could be hard to debug.
The reason are undeclared variables in the script, essentialy making them shareable across iFlow instances. You should declare all variables, at least with 'def'.
See SAP Note 3457571 for details, could save you from trouble in high load scenarios.

Best regards,
Thomas

SAP AI Training im SAP Learning Hub

Mit einem SAP Learning Hub Abo gibt es viele zus√§tzliche "premium" Lernangebote wie Live-Sessions durch Experten, √úbungs-systeme, Zertifizierungs-Gutscheine sowie Zertifizierungs-Updates, Learning Analytics und vieles mehr. Anbei ausgew√§hlte KI Inhalte:

Diese Zertifizierung  best√§tigt, dass du SAPs Business AI-Funktionen verstehst und √ºber die F√§higkeiten verf√ºgst, SAP BTP-Anwendungen zu erweitern, w√§hrend du f√ºhrende Large Language Models (LLMs) nutzt, unter Verwendung von SAP AI Core/SAP AI Launchpad und SAPs Generative AI Hub.

Wie lange dauert der Abschluss von SAP AI Lernpfaden?

Wie starte ich mit SAP AI Training?

entry.title: CAP - How to Update Association of Remote Entity without Duplicating Entries in Local DB ?
entry.content:
Dear Reader, 

I have a question about how to deal with remote associations when updating their values from my local CAP application.

Imagine having a schema like this:

entity Products : cuid {
    name  : String;
    price : Integer;
    order : Association to Orders;
    /*
    totalQuantiy : type of order.TotalQuantity;
    startDate    : type of order.MfgOrderPlannedStartDate;
    endDate      : type of order.MfgOrderPlannedEndDate;
    */
}

entity Orders                      as
    projection on API_PRODUCTION_ORDER_2_SRV {
        key ManufacturingOrder,
            TotalQuantity,
            MfgOrderPlannedStartDate,
            MfgOrderPlannedEndDate,
    }

My local CAP application has a Fiori-Eelements frontend and displays all the fields of "Products" in an object page and I dynamically add associated fields to "TotalQuantity", "StartDate" and "EndDate" from remote entity "Orders". So when I am reading my "Products" I expand the read to the remote entity with my custom handler, everything is fine. 

But what if I want to update certain elements, like "TotalQuantity", "StartDate" and "EndDate" from the remote entity?
My Entity "Products" is draft enabled, but changes in the fields "TotalQuantity", "StartDate" and "EndDate" of the association are not triggering any "PUSH" or "UPDATE" event in the backend. 

The problem is, I don't want to persistently add the fields "TotalQuantity", "StartDate" and "EndDate" to the entity "Products", that is why I added them in /* */.
I tried making them virtual or computed fields, but then they are also read-only for the Fiori frontend and no event is triggered when changing them. New values are also not delivered to the backend on "save" button in the frontend. 

So the question for me remains, is it only possible to send draft values from the frontend to the backend on persistently saved elements ?
or is there another way I am missing, to somehow allow me to change the values in the fields "TotalQuantity", "StartDate" and "EndDate" and receive the new values in the backend, so I can update the remote entity ?

I hope i explained the problem somehow understandable, otherwise feel free to tell me so I can update üôÇ 

thanks for your time, greetings

David

entry.title: Re: Internal error (3998) occurred [Message 131-183] when adding document in SAP B1
entry.content:
Hello Asim,

From what i remember this had to do with the permissions of the (new in version 10) users xx_RW and xx_RO users. Depending on how you restore/update the test DB, you might be overwriting the existing _RW and _RO users with those of the live db. After you do a "refresh database user" in the SLD for the test database, it refreshes these users and their permissions so then you need to double check they have the required one.

I think you need to see in SLD which RW and RO user is assigned to that test DB, then go into the SQL server and see what permissions the corresponding users have on the live databases (which i suppose are working fine) and then apply these on the RW and RO users of the test database.

Hope that helps,

Spyros

entry.title: Re: I am facing issue while debugging SAP MDK code in VS...
entry.content:
It looks like you are using definitions received from App Update.  Please verify that when the metadata was deployed from BAS to Mobile Services you answered Yes to the "Include source map file for debugging?" question.

You can confirm this by looking at the .project.json for the SourceMap option

	"Build": {
		"SourceMap": true,
		"TSTarget": "es6",
		"WMF": true,
		"Platform": "iOS & Android"
	},

If it is false, change it to true and redeploy from BAS.  Then update the definitions on your client from Mobile Services and try again.

To show the Y-axis in your SAP Analytics Cloud chart, follow these steps:

  3. Go to More Options > Show/Hide.

Hi @Anandasai 

To show the Y-axis in your SAP Analytics Cloud chart, follow these steps:

  1. Click on the chart to activate it.
  2. Click the three dots (More Actions) in the top-left corner of the chart.

entry.title: Re: SAP DIGITAL MANUFACTURING - TRANSFER ERP PERSONNEL NUMBER in COMPLETE SFC - YELD CONFIRM
entry.content:
Hi Antonio,

just to make sure I understood your enquiry.

1. You have one SFC under a order with a quantity of larger then 1

2. The user enters the POD with a badge in advance

3. You are entering a partial quantity confirmation means the SFC will be at operation 1 and operation 2 since relaxed routing is active

4. Your issue: You want the Badge Number of the respective user confirmed as the personel number within the quantity confirmation, right?

You said the following "... a partial quantity using API /sfcs/complete". Does this means that you are using the API to confirm quantities or do you use a production process which is calling the "Complete SFCs" business service? And why are you not using the normal SFC Complete? But regardless of that, I think you can't map the "batch" number easily into the "PERS_NO" field of the workflow you are using for the confirmation. I was taking a look into the CPI to see if the batch number is available to be mapped but unfortunately thats not the case. 

Cheers,

Kevin

entry.title: Performance Rethought: LLM Standards in Embedded AI
entry.content:
üöÄFrom Milliseconds to Minutes: Why Everything You Know About Performance is About to Change

Gone are the days when 200ms was considered slow. Welcome to the era where waiting 10 seconds for an AI response isn't just acceptable‚Äîit's revolutionary. If you're building LLM-powered applications and still thinking in traditional performance metrics, you're not just behind the curve‚Äîyou're on the wrong curve entirely.

This isn't your typical performance optimization guide. It's a deep dive into the uncharted waters of AI application development, where the rules have fundamentally changed and the playbook is still being written. Buckle up for a comprehensive technical journey that will reshape how you think about performance, quality, and user experience in the age of embedded AI.

‚ö°What You're About to Discover:

  • Why traditional KPIs are not just inadequate‚Äîthey're misleading
  • The hidden variables that actually control LLM performance (spoiler: it's not your server specs)
  • How to make 15-second responses feel faster than 3-second ones
  • The monitoring strategies that separate successful AI products from failed experiments
  • Real-world approaches to testing systems that give different answers to the same question

Ready to navigate the new reality of multi-second interactions and redefine what "good performance" actually means? Let's dive in.

Table of Contents

 

Section

Topic

1

The LLM Performance Reality Check

2

Redefining Performance Standards

3

Mastering Non-Deterministic Systems

4

User Experience for Multi-Second Interactions

5

Technical Implementation Guidelines

6

Modern Monitoring Approaches

7

Cost-Performance Optimization

8

Quality Assurance Strategies

9

Future-Proofing Your Architecture

10

Building Sustainable AI Products

 

1. The LLM Performance Reality Check

The world of application performance has fundamentally shifted. Traditional applications where we optimized for 50ms, 200ms, or 400ms response times have given way to AI-powered systems where meaningful interactions can take 5, 10, or even 30+ seconds. This isn't a performance problem to solve ‚Äì it's a new paradigm to design around.

Based on experience from Gen AI POC development and performance engineering work, the fundamental challenge isn't making LLM applications faster ‚Äì it's redefining what "acceptable performance" means when core computation happens in external systems beyond our control. Every LLM request is essentially an external API call with inherently unpredictable response times.

This reality requires a complete rethink of product standards, user experience design, and performance measurement approaches. The community needs practical guidelines for navigating this new landscape while still delivering value to users.

2. Redefining Performance Standards

Traditional performance KPIs don't translate effectively to LLM-based applications. While conventional applications target 1-3 seconds for simple tasks or maximum 5 seconds for complex operations, AI-powered applications operate in a fundamentally different performance landscape.

Key Performance Variables

The factors that significantly impact LLM response times include:

Model Selection: Different models (GPT-4, Claude, LLaMA variants, or specialized models) have distinct performance profiles. Smaller models might deliver responses in 2-3 seconds for simple tasks, while larger models could require 10-15 seconds for the same query.

Token Economics: Both input and output token counts dramatically affect response time. A prompt with 1,000 tokens might take twice as long as a 500-token prompt with identical model configurations.

Infrastructure and Deployment: Provisioned deployments vs. on-demand services can show 3-5x performance variance. Provisioned deployments might consistently deliver 2-second responses, while shared infrastructure could require 8-10 seconds during peak usage.

Prompt Complexity: Compute-bound tasks (mathematical reasoning, code generation) vs. memory-bound tasks (text completion, summarization) exhibit different performance characteristics.

Additional Variables to Consider:

  • Geographic proximity to inference endpoints
  • Network latency and bandwidth constraints
  • Concurrent request load on shared infrastructure
  • Model warming and cold start effects
  • Request queuing and throttling mechanisms

Setting Realistic Performance Standards

An effective approach should focus on business context rather than arbitrary time limits:

A. Production-Like Testing: Prefer testing with realistic data volumes and production-equivalent infrastructure rather than development environment metrics.

B. Scenario-Based Benchmarking: The approach should establish performance expectations based on specific user scenarios. Creative writing assistants might justify 10-second responses, while customer service chatbots need sub-3-second replies.

C. Perceived Performance Priority: Streaming responses can make a 10-second interaction feel more responsive than a 3-second batch response, making user perception more valuable than raw response time metrics.

3. Mastering Non-Deterministic Systems

Traditional software testing assumes deterministic outputs ‚Äì the same input should always produce the same output. LLM applications fundamentally challenge this assumption, requiring new approaches to testing and validation.

Common Variability Patterns

In POC development and use case testing, identical prompts commonly produce:

  • Varying response lengths (200 words vs. 500 words for the same request)
  • Different accuracy levels under system load
  • Inconsistent formatting and structure
  • Variable response times even with identical infrastructure

A practical example: document-based GenAI use cases under normal load might provide detailed, accurate analysis. During stress testing with concurrent requests, the same system might deliver superficial analysis and occasionally generate information not present in the trained dataset.

Testing Approach for Non-Deterministic Systems

A. Baseline Establishment: The preferred approach involves sending identical prompts 10-20 times to understand natural variation ranges before implementing load testing.

B.Quality Metrics Under Load: Performance testing should encompass maintaining output quality as system load increases, not just response speed.

C.Response Validation Frameworks: Teams should implement pattern-matching approaches to validate that responses contain expected key elements, even when exact wording varies.

4. User Experience for Multi-Second Interactions

The shift from millisecond to multi-second interactions has forced a complete rethink of user experience design. Users have different expectations when they know they're interacting with AI, but those expectations need to be carefully managed.

Streaming: The Game Changer

Implementing streaming responses represents the most impactful UX improvement for LLM applications. When users see tokens appearing in real-time, a 15-second response feels interactive rather than sluggish. The psychological effect is significant ‚Äì users perceive the system as "thinking out loud" rather than being unresponsive.

Managing Expectations Through Design

Transparency works better than trying to hide the AI nature of interactions:

  • Progress Indicators: The preferable approach uses contextual messages like "Analyzing your document..." or "Generating recommendations..." instead of generic loading spinners
  • Time Estimates: When possible, provide rough time estimates based on request complexity
  • Cancellation Options: Long-running requests should include escape mechanisms

Continuous Feedback Mechanisms

LLM applications require different feedback approaches than traditional immediate-response applications:

  • Real-time streaming for immediate engagement
  • Intermediate results for complex multi-step tasks
  • Post-response quality feedback to improve future interactions

5. Technical Implementation Guidelines

LLM-based applications require fundamentally different monitoring approaches than traditional applications. These systems should integrate with APM tools like Dynatrace for comprehensive observability alongside specialized LLM metrics.

Understanding the LLM Processing Pipeline

LLM processing involves distinct stages, each with different optimization strategies:

  • Queue Time: Duration requests wait before processing begins
  • Prefill Stage: Initial input prompt processing (compute-bound)
  • Decode/Inference Stage: Token-by-token generation (memory-bound)
  • Inter-token Latency: Time between individual token generations

Tools like vLLM provide visibility into these stages for performance optimization.

Hardware Constraint Considerations

Based on experience, hardware limitations often become bottlenecks before software optimizations matter:

GPU Power Limits: Systems might hit power limits (e.g., 350W), causing performance throttling that reduces throughput by 40-50%. DCGM metrics monitoring becomes essential for identifying these constraints.

Memory Bandwidth: The memory-bound nature of decode phases means GPU memory bandwidth often limits token generation speed more than compute capacity.

Thermal Throttling: Extended high-load operations can cause thermal throttling, leading to unpredictable performance degradation.

Infrastructure Monitoring Requirements

Effective LLM monitoring should consider both application-level and hardware-level metrics:

Application Metrics:

  • Time to First Token (TTFT)
  • Token generation rate
  • Queue depth and wait times
  • Request completion rates

Hardware Metrics:

  • GPU utilization and clock frequencies
  • Power consumption and thermal status
  • Memory utilization patterns
  • Network I/O for distributed inference

6. Modern Monitoring Approaches

Traditional APM tools require extension for LLM applications. The approach should encompass comprehensive observability beyond standard metrics.

Multi-Dimensional Performance Tracking

LLM performance requires tracking multiple dimensions simultaneously:

  1. Latency Distribution: P50, P90, P95, and P99 percentiles rather than just average response time
  2. Quality Degradation: Response accuracy and completeness under various load conditions
  3. Resource Utilization: Both compute and financial resource consumption
  4. User Satisfaction: Direct feedback correlation with performance metrics

Advanced Alerting Strategies

Standard latency-based alerting doesn't suit LLM applications. Teams should develop:

  • Quality-based alerts: Triggered when response accuracy drops below acceptable thresholds
  • Cost threshold alerts: Activated when per-request costs exceed budget parameters
  • Capacity planning alerts: Indicating when queue times suggest scaling needs

7. Cost-Performance Optimization

LLM applications present unique cost-performance challenges. Unlike traditional applications where better hardware improves performance, AI systems face complex cost-performance matrices requiring strategic optimization.

LLM Economics Considerations

Model Selection Impact: Premium models might provide better quality but cost 10-20x more than alternatives like GPT-3.5-turbo or GPT-4o-mini for similar tasks. Performance differences might be marginal for many use cases.

Token Optimization: Prompt engineering for token efficiency improves both performance and cost. Reducing input prompts from 1,000 to 500 tokens speeds responses and halves costs.

Deployment Model Economics: Provisioned throughput models offer predictable performance but require minimum commitments. Pay-per-use models provide flexibility with performance variability.

Cost-Performance Optimization Approach

A.Use Case Classification: Not every interaction requires the most powerful model

  1. Dynamic Model Selection: Route simple queries to faster, more economical models
  2. Caching Strategies: Implement intelligent caching for repeated or similar queries
  3. Load Balancing: Distribute requests across different model deployments based on cost and performance requirements

8. Quality Assurance Strategies

Quality assurance for LLM applications requires a fundamentally different approach than traditional software testing. Functional testing, performance testing, and quality testing are inseparably intertwined.

QA Approach for Non-Deterministic Systems

Behavioral Testing: Instead of testing for exact outputs, focus on behavioral consistency. The system should maintain appropriate tone, accuracy level, and response structure across different scenarios.

Load-Quality Correlation: System load often impacts response quality before affecting response time. Quality degradation can serve as an early warning sign of infrastructure stress.

Regression Testing: Traditional regression testing doesn't work when outputs vary naturally. The approach should test for maintained capability rather than identical outputs.

Quality Metrics to Track

  • Response Relevance: How well does the output address the input query?
  • Factual Accuracy: For knowledge-based tasks, accuracy under various load conditions
  • Consistency: Variation in response quality for similar inputs
  • Safety and Appropriateness: Maintaining safety guardrails under stress

9. Future-Proofing Your Architecture

Building LLM applications requires planning for constant change in this rapidly evolving field.

Technical Architecture Considerations

Model Agnostic Design: Build applications that can switch between different LLM providers and models without major architectural changes.

Scalable Infrastructure: The infrastructure needs to handle both current workloads and rapid scaling as user adoption grows.

Monitoring and Observability: Comprehensive logging and monitoring become even more critical when dealing with external AI services.

Business Planning for AI Applications

Cost Modeling: LLM costs can scale unpredictably with user growth. Build in cost monitoring and alerting from day one.

Performance SLA Management: Set realistic expectations with stakeholders about AI application performance characteristics.

Continuous Optimization: Unlike traditional applications that reach stable performance, LLM applications require ongoing optimization as models, infrastructure, and usage patterns evolve.

10. Building Sustainable AI Products

Success requires embracing the fundamental differences rather than trying to force AI into traditional application paradigms.

Core Recommendations

A. Accept the Performance Reality: Multi-second response times aren't bugs to fix ‚Äì they're characteristics to design around.

B. Focus on Business Value: The question isn't whether a 10-second response is fast enough, but whether the value provided justifies the wait for specific use cases.

C. Invest in User Experience: Streaming, progress indication, and expectation management are more important than raw performance optimization.

D. Build Comprehensive Monitoring: Traditional metrics aren't sufficient. Teams need visibility into quality, cost, and user satisfaction alongside performance.

E. Plan for Variability: Both performance and quality will vary. Design systems that gracefully handle this variability rather than trying to eliminate it.

F. Gather Direct User Feedback: In the absence of standard benchmarks, user satisfaction becomes the ultimate performance metric.

The LLM application landscape continues evolving rapidly. These guidelines represent practical approaches based on current experience, but practices will continue evolving as the technology matures. The key is building systems that can adapt to this evolution while delivering consistent value to users.

Organizations that succeed will embrace the unique characteristics of AI applications rather than trying to make them behave like traditional software. The future belongs to products that harness AI power while managing its constraints thoughtfully and transparently.

These insights draw on hands-on experience from Gen AI development and performance engineering. By sharing practical learnings, the community can collectively advance in building robust LLM-based applications.

What challenges have you faced in your own use cases, and which approaches have proven most effective? Sharing experiences and solutions will help the broader community navigate this evolving space.

The SAP Community is an online platform where users, developers, consultants, and business professionals interact and share knowledge related to SAP software solutions. SAP (Systems, Applications, and Products in Data Processing) is one of the world‚Äôs leading enterprise resource planning (ERP) software providers, and the SAP Community serves as a hub for information, collaboration, and support around the SAP ecosystem.

Here are some key features of the SAP Community:

  1. Discussion Forums: Users can ask questions, share experiences, and get answers from experts. The forums cover a wide range of SAP topics, from specific modules (like SAP S/4HANA, SAP Fiori, SAP BW) to development and integration.

  2. Blogs: Industry experts, SAP professionals, and developers post articles about SAP products, best practices, tutorials, and new trends in the SAP world.

  3. Knowledge Base: A collection of helpful documentation, guides, and how-to articles, often contributed by community members or SAP itself.

  4. Q&A Section: Similar to platforms like Stack Overflow, where users can post questions and receive answers, often rated by quality.

  5. Events & Webinars: The community often hosts or shares information about SAP-related events, webinars, conferences (like SAP TechEd), and user groups.

  6. Open Source Projects: It‚Äôs a place for developers to collaborate on open-source projects related to SAP, sharing code and solutions with others.

  7. SAP Mentors: These are recognized experts who volunteer their time to help others in the community, answer questions, and provide guidance.

  8. Collaboration: Members can join specific groups based on their interests (such as SAP Cloud Platform, SAP HANA, or SAP Development) to collaborate on specialized topics.

 

Are you working with SAP, or just curious about it?

entry.title: Onboarding 2.0 - Modify Task Due Date
entry.content:
We would like to modify the due dates assigned to new hires in Onboarding to be based on when we initiate onboarding versus being related to the new hires start date.

Example:

  1. We extend an offer to a candidate 9/1/25 with an anticipated start date of 10/1/25
  2. Candidate accepts offer 9/2/25.
  3. We initiate Onboarding 9/3/25.
  4. We would like all new hire Onboarding tasks to be completed within 2 days of initiating Onboarding.  In this example, all new hire Onboarding tasks should be completed by 9/5/25.

Has anyone had any luck assigning due dates that are not related to the start date?  It seems to me that due dates can only be built based on the start date, for example, 5 days before start date.

entry.title: Re: Account 50160030 requires an assignment to a CO objec...
entry.content:
Hi @Dasun_T ,

It seems you're running interest calculation program and interest GL account needs a cost center.

You need to assign default GL & cost center in t-code OKB9.

If your interest expense account is the one failing in FINTAP, add it in OKB9 with a default cost center ‚Üí that should clear the error.

Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: SAP Cloud Public intercompany process vs. SAP ECC is...
entry.content:
HI @rekafulop ,

Here‚Äôs a tabular summary of the relevant functionality / limitations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, it relates to your scenario (intercompany time recording, auto-reversals, project assignment etc.)

Function / ProcessStatus in Public CloudRelevant Limitation(s)SAP Note / KBA ReferenceLink
Auto-reverse of journal entries for intercompany postingsNot supportedAuto-reverse not allowed for intercompany journal entries. Must reverse manually.KBA 3137078SAP KBA 3137078
Reversal of journal entries across fiscal yearsRestrictedCannot reverse if reversal date falls in different fiscal year from original posting.KBA 3079612SAP KBA 3079612
Cost assignment to project / WBS from manual journals / service postingsPartially supportedCertain manual journals do not allow project/WBS assignment; restrictions exist for activity types / cost center categories.KBA 2864151SAP KBA 2864151
Time recording ‚Üí project work packages / WBS elementsSupportedStandard time recording works; limitation is mainly around reversals and duplicate postings from multiple sources.Learning JourneyLearning.sap.com Time Recording
Purchase Requisition / PO account assignment ‚ÄúProject (P)‚Äù + Cost CenterIssue / BugWhen copying PR lines, old project assignments may remain ‚Üí double assignment (Cost Center + Project).KBA 3542501SAP KBA 3542501
Default cost object ‚ÄúProject‚Äù in expense reportsAvailableCan default project instead of cost center in employee settings (‚ÄúMy Data / Personalize‚Äù).KBA 1971120SAP KBA 1971120

 

  • The duplication likely arises because the initial time entry (from SuccessFactors) is posted, and then another entry (from Excel upload) also posts cost. Since there is no auto‚Äêreversal for the first intercompany type entry, both remain active.

  • If the system disallows project assignment on the reversing entry or offsetting entry (because of manual journal / rule restrictions), then you can‚Äôt correct it correctly in the project dimension.

 

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI.
Thanks,
Divyesh
